feels.name: Trust
feels.quote: Remember, dear, I’m the only one left—I mean, there’s no one to be hurt by what I do. I’m willing to do anything that’s right and honest; and I don’t think, if Deborah knows where she is, she’ll care so very much if I’m not genteel; because, you see, she’ll know all, dear. Only let me see what I can do, and pay the poor people as far as I’m able.

causedBy.name: Feeling responsible for the poor people

feels.exactPlace: Before going out for a walk with Mary's father

feels.name: Sadness
feels.quote: She recovered herself into a slight degree of impatient anger, directed against me, as having set them all off; and, moreover, I think she was vexed that I could not make a speech back in return for hers; and if I had known beforehand what was to be said, and had a card on which to express the probable feelings that would rise in my heart, I would have tried to gratify her. As it was, Mrs Forrester was the person to speak when we had recovered our composure.

causedBy.name: Feeling unable to express her gratitude adequately

feels.exactPlace: During the meeting with the Cranford ladies

feels.name: Anxiety
feels.quote: Miss Matty and I sat assenting to accounts, and schemes, and reports, and documents, of which I do not believe we either of us understood a word; for my father was clear-headed and decisive, and a capital man of business, and if we made the slightest inquiry, or expressed the slightest want of comprehension, he had a sharp way of saying, “Eh? eh? it’s as clear as daylight. What’s your objection?”

causedBy.name: Feeling overwhelmed by the business discussions

feels.exactPlace: During the business discussions with Mary's father

Places.name: Miss Pole's drawing-room
Places.description: Arranged for a secret meeting to discuss helping Miss Matty

Places.name: Miss Matty's house
Places.description: Preparing for retrenchment and giving up the house

Events.name: Meeting of the Cranford ladies at Miss Pole's
